description:
my boyfriend says "this is what i imagine asian diner food to be like" and i say "YES that's pretty much exactly what it is!" 

This place is what I expect out of a hong kong style cafe. The food, snacks, and desserts remind me of my child, but disclaimer... i've never actually been to HK so you'll just have to read this review coming from an Asian-American kid at heart.

My absolute favorite thing they have is the soft tofu dessert. Only on Fridays & Saturdays!! But you also just can't go wrong with curry fishballs or any of their plates. Spaghetti noodles and pork chops?? Count me in to go again and again!

I think the store is family run since I only ever see the same 4 people taking orders, bussing tables, and working in the kitchen area (as far as I can see, anyway), and they definitely are pretty efficient, though there is some tabling-to-kitchen communication that happens (aka some yelling in cantonese from time to time).
author: Nadine F.

description:
Had the green tea ice cream waffle. While the flavor of the waffle, and nice and crisp, there was too much ice cream that took away from the waffle when eaten together _ lacking balance. 

The popcorn chicken....can't tell if it's missing something or just stale. It appears that it was fried, cut, then stored. Then refried to order. The batter is bland. Lacks seasoning and flavor. I'm usually a fan of popcorn chicken, but never again from here.
author: Eric S.

description:
I was so excited to walk in and see all my favorite Hong Kong desserts that I grew up on!!!  ESPECIALLY black sesame :D.  I wish I lived here and could come every day and I mean it!

My friend and I happened to bike by in the morning, and decided to stop by after lunch and massage for dessert (this sequence of events HIGHLY RECOMMENDED).  It was about 3 PM on a Saturday when we sauntered in all loosey goosey from our massages - the owner was kind, we were quickly served once we FINALLY decided what to get.  I LOVED my black sesame dessert (better than the powdered one I get/love at 99 Ranch!!).  My friend who was not Asian liked this place as well!!  :) :) Bring your friends!!  I also got a black sesame egg puff to go.  I enjoyed the roasted black sesame flavor in the subtle egg puff.

Everyone should just relax and just enjoy their favorite dessert at this lovely, homey cafe.  :)

I will say that I briefly looked at the check at the end, I noticed there were two tables of the same tip percentages on the same check, but the dollar amounts didn't match.  It didn't bug me too much, but for some reason I feel that a mathy customer soon may work out the math and point out the discrepancy to the owner :)
author: Samantha C.

description:
tl;dr lovely spot for late night dessert with a huge menu!

My boyfriend explained to me the bizarre cyber-punk anarchy that was Kowloon as we approached this place. Now, forget that because this place really has nothing to do with that and Kowloon Walled City was demolished in 1993. 

Aaaanyway, I loved this place. It was colorful and as soon as you sit down, they plop down a colorful, tall cup of cold water in front of you. They have an extensive menu--sago, custard, milkshakes, puffles--whatever you want! They also have tons of tempting savory options. We ordered the mango pudding, mixed fruit sago, and the original milk custard. I've never had sago, so maybe take my opinion with a grain of salt, but I loved it! It reminded me very much of the tapioca coconut kheer at DOSA. The custard was good but I definitely should've gotten a flavor instead of the original because it was a bit plain, but I imagine some people are into that.

This place is open till 1 am, and for either late night dessert cravings or late night drunchies, you can't beat it.
author: Claire C.

description: Not exactly my favorite dessert place. The first few times I came here, I tried the Mixed Fruit Sago. It was delicious but some fruits such as the honeydew was not sweet. Also their popcorn chicken is really sweet but their fries are more oily and saltier than expected compared to other snack places I went.
author: Joey D.

description: My fav dessert place. Been coming here for years since they open. I usually get their ham egg sandwich, egg puff, mix fruit, garlic fried chicken wings, HK milk tea and soy sauce wings. The garlic fried chicken, HK milk tea and egg puff a must order.  Free ice cream sandwich when checked in on yelp and spend over $40.
author: Christy V.

description:
Hong Kong-styled dessert cafe! Kowloon serves late-night snacks and desserts such as shaved ice drinks, appetizers (like egg puffs, waffles, wings), and cold/hot desserts specializing in mango sagos, sesame paste, and glutinous balls. I like the crafty variety of dessert blends and toppings, but taste-wise - it is pretty subpar.

When I come to Kowloon, I typically order egg puffs, mango sago, and a sesame paste dessert. It's nothing really special - tastes alright at best. I particularly like going here mostly for the ambiance. It's a great place to catch up with friends and grab a late-night snack. 

Other than that, I would recommend you go elsewhere for better quality food and desserts.
author: Michelle L.

description: My personal favorites are anything in the sago category. I love all Asian deserts because they are not too sweet and many of them have fruits in it.
author: Andrea T.

description: Workers are so friendly! I like come here with my friends. Especially, they close pretty late than other dessert places :)
author: Michelle W.

description:
TL;DR classic asian late night dessert for sago 

Check in on Yelp for the free waffle ice cream if you spend more than $40. You'll need to order around 8 items for the freebie, perfect if you have a large group. The most popular dishes are the black sesame, mango desserts, and wings. I really like the black sesame almond paste, everything else is just meh. The ice cream isn't that good, just Dreyers. They're usually pretty busy at night, maybe a 15-30 minute wait, maybe even more on Fridays and weekends.
author: Sophia L.

description:
I was so excited to find a Hong Kong dessert with all the classics! The place was very busy on a Saturday night but they were quick in moving people through the line. We tried the sweet tofu and steamed egg dessert. The tofu was a bit too rough and not our favorite, but we loved the steamed egg (both the original flavor and ginger flavor). Service is friendly, great, and quick.

I'll have to come back to try to rice crepes which looked pretty good!
author: Jacqui C.

description:
Kowloon Tong Dessert Café was worth a visit.  Nothing special; to me is as good as it gets.  Being here reminds me that I'm in Kowloon HK, looking for a place to have a dessert.  I picked one of the weekends that starts at 3 pm.  Dinner nights aren't my best choices in the dessert café; however, I'm glad it stays open on late nights until 2 am, only if I need something to eat.

I came here to Kowloon Tong for anything that's sweet and warm for dessert, black sesame & almond paste was one of them.  I went inside say 3:15 and have a seat when the owner was already making my chosen dessert in less than twenty minutes.  After few minutes of waiting, I was surprised mine came to me.  I already know how black sesame taste like; the almond flavor is what I used to have straight from the powdered can, thicker than almond milk but sweeter.  I wanted to go for deep fried soya tofu blocks, but I rather savor for another time.

I'm glad there weren't more people coming in here when I first came.  Customer service was good in a big family run dessert café.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
My friends and I decided to stop by here for some Asian dessert. It was bustling with people around 11pm. There was a small wait but it moved fairly quickly. We were seated and handed menus. The menu had both small snacks and desserts. A very big selection, so it took us awhile to decide. 

I got the steamed egg/steamed custard in the coconut milk. The steamed egg was very smooth and silky. While I was eating it, I could taste the creaminess of the coconut. I just wish was sweeter. The coconut milk is literally just coconut milk. I also got the glutinous balls in paste- red bean balls in coconut milk sago. The red bean balls were so good; they were filled with a sweet red bean flavor soaked in coconut milk. Again, the coconut milk was very plain and not sweet at all. The only sweetness I got was from the red bean. 

My bf got the waffle and ice cream (you have purchase $40 or more and check in on Yelp to get this dessert for free). It tasted very regular...just vanilla ice cream drizzled with Nutella and a waffle sandwich on the outside. 

My friends got the sesame and glutinous balls and the fruit sago. She said the sesame tasted like the instant sesame dessert. So not really sure if it was made fresh or not. 

We also ordered the salt and pepper chicken wings. It was very crispy and crunchy so I liked it! It came in a plate of 5, so fairly small. I will have to be back for their other desserts and snacks. 

I really like this place but I wish the desserts were sweeter. What would it be if it wasn't sweet? Definitely not a dessert.
author: Vanessa T.

description: This place has very authentic HK desserts ! Highly recommend the Sesame Glutinous Balls with sesame paste
author: Julie T.

description:
This place is excellent for a late-night sweet treat! There's not many Chinese/Taiwanese dessert & snack joints in the city but this one is great. They open till midnight and there's plenty of seating and a good crowd. Their service is quick and friendly!

I came for there waffle sandwich ice cream which is delicious. The waffle is cakey and made fresh with a nice sweet batter. The sandwich itself holds still and doesn't break apart. I personally would rather have a waffle ice cream sandwich anyway over cookie ice cream sandwiches. 

If you're looking for a late night dessert joint after a night of bar-hopping, then I'd recommend Kowloon!
author: Allister D.

description:
My friends and I were craving dessert after having dinner in the city on a Thursday night. They suggested this place for Hong Kong style desserts. I love shaved ice so I was especially down to try it here. 
This place was packed!! We had to scout out for an open table.
But the desserts were just meh...

Strawberry shaved ice- the ice was not finely shaved at all (i.e. had some huge chunks) and had no flavor besides the diluted condensed milk it was swimming in with a few sour strawberry pieces. So disappointing.

Green tea ice cream waffle sandwich- I liked it better than my shaved ice. The ice cream was rich and creamy and made up for the waffle that tasted like the frozen Eggo ones. 

Overall, just an OK place to get some late night dessert with friends.
author: Yvi L.

description:
I'm always craving for asian desserts and I heard of this place so long ago but I was finally able to come here yesterday! This place is out of my way but we came here after dinner in the area.

This dessert shop itself has a lot of seating but it is still packed! Fortunately, my boyfriend and I got seated right away before the rush came.

We ordered:

**HK Style Milk Tea - So good! I haven't had REALLY good milk tea in a while and I was really impressed with their milk tea. Comparable to actual milk tea from Hong Kong!

**Red Bean Shaved Ice - It was very icy. I thought it was red bean flavored shaved ice but it is actually vanilla or condensed milk shaved us with actual red bean. The red bean was good but I thought the shaved ice itself was too icy.

**Mango pudding - This was good! Even the fresh mangoes when mangoes aren't in season!

I really enjoy this HK style dessert shop. They have good items on their menu and a wide selection too. It is a great place for all ages and it opens until 2am!
author: Allie Y.

description:
Kowloon tong is my go to place for a late night snack! Whether I want a milkshake and fries or some panfried noodles and ramen, this is THE PLACE. 

Kind servers, always welcoming! Food is brought out fresh as well. 

I ordered popcorn chicken, taro in coconut milk with sweet sticky rice (BOMB), and a honey lemon hot drink.
author: Kiana M.

description: Kowloon is a classic and always here for anyone who needs a late night snack! The food is delicious and open late. It reminds me of the 626. Everyone gets the mango sago and egg puff waffles. Below is the mango sago, chocolate egg puff waffle and pan fried egg with spam spicy noodles. Great memz are created here :')
author: Caitlyn S.

description:
This place seems cool because there have a lot of yummy looking HK-style desserts, but the taste & experience was not good.

1. Everything is quite expensive and the taste is so-so, especially for the jelly-based dishes (i.e. the sagos), which I would not get. Contrary to some other reviews, the sago that we tried was very thin and flavorless and the portion was a lot smaller than other dessert places. 

2. The service is horrendous. The place was super busy when I was there and it was understaffed, so it took forever for the waiter to take our order, make the food, and deliver it to us
author: Amy G.

description: The Chinese worker with the glasses is soooo nice. I was being so complicated but he delt with me and remained friendly the whole time. The food is average but the service was great. He even brought me my egg puff outside the door while it was super busy.
author: Irene Z.

description: Lots of variety of desserts. The ice cream waffle sandwich was really good. The waffle to ice cream ratio was perfect. This place also serves food so you can come here for both dinner and dessert. :)
author: Kaitlyn I.

description:
There aren't a lot of places to eat open until 1am.

Kowloon Tong doesn't have the best Chinese desserts, but they have a whole menu of really affordable savory snacks that I have no complaints about.  There is 100% nothing wrong with fried egg noodles with spam at 12am.  You just can't come in expecting a fancy 3 course dinner and the service to match.  It's a casual cafe, and they thankfully just leave you be to ingest as many unhealthy calories as you desire.

My friends and I like getting the noodles and various fried things.  Toast is pretty decent because you can't really mess that up.  I've had the ginger milk custard, and it's not as good as Golden Island, but this place is far less crowded.  

Tips and Tricks
-Tends to fill up as the night goes on, so earlier is better to snag a seat
-They let you sit for hours, as long as there aren't people waiting.  Just flag someone over if you need refills of hot tea
author: Jessica L.

description: Been coming here since my college years for some cheap late night eats. My go to is the mango sago which has never failed me. The rest of the food is meh. Almost feels like they run over to the Smart and Final next door for their hot food prep.
author: Jonathan A.

description: This restaurant is pretty popular. I came on Wednesday night but it is still almost full. The food is all right and the service is good.
author: Kkkl Z.

description: We arrived to the wait staff being no where in sight, so we just sat ourselves. It took five minutes for someone to notice we had arrived so they could give us menus. Ordering was fine and the selection is decent. The reason we walked out before even getting our food was a group of four people screaming at each other all around the restaurant for ten minutes, and the wait staff doing nothing about it. The man doing the most screaming was not even asked to leave. The waitstaff was acting as if it was funny. There are much better options for dessert places in the Richmond with more attentive staff.
author: Adam A.

description: I am always amazed at the random assortment of food available at Hong Kong style cafes, at very reasonable prices. From Asian desserts like steamed egg custards to chicken steak sandwich, to nutella toast, anything! I got a mango sago, which is mango slices over a tapioca like pudding. Solid and relatively refreshing dessert. Our large group of 8 was seated quickly, our waiter was friendly and attentive, and overall relaxed atmosphere. We were constantly provided hot tea, which was much appreciated on that cold night. There is generally a young crowd here (e.g. high schoolers), but still a good spot nonetheless.
author: Annie L.

description:
While the mango-go-go was good enough, I don't recommend the egg puff (you're better off going to Genki for the egg puff!). I think overall, it's good to stay away from the batter stuff here (ie - waffle, egg puff), but order the sago stuff, the mango-go-go, anything mango, anything soup based, is similar to what you can get in HK. 

I'm a bit picky here because I've lived in HK for a while and crave HK desserts all the time!!! So when I get my HK dessert fix, I like it to be as close to what I used to get as possible :(
author: Dana Z.

description: Went to the restaurant this afternoon. Food is just so so. When I was paying the check, I surprisedly found they already included 18% tips. We are only group of 4 , I saw no reason to pre-add the tips. I asked why, and they told me this is just how they do things.
author: 天远

description:
Kowloon is a typical Hong Kong type of cafe which I grew up with in SoCal -- though more focused on sweet stuff. They have your typical cafe favorites like popcorn chicken, noodles, and stir-fries. But again, this is mainly a dessert place. They have a pretty good selection of waffles, rice balls, and warm/hot dessert soups with red bean, taro, coconut milk, etc. (Very nostalgic and homey flavors if you grew up in an Asian household.) While the popcorn chicken was pretty good, it didn't have the crunch, bite, or heat I am accustomed to at other spots (i.e. "chain" boba joints like Lollicup or Ten Ren). 

The servers are friendly and relatively attentive given how busy it got on a *weekday* night. In terms of ambiance, this is a no-frills cafe but in the best possible way. Most of the patrons were young or young-ish -- mainly teenagers and college students hanging out with friends. I saw a couple families as well. Kowloon is open late so, if anything, this is a fantastic place if you have late night Asian food cravings. And, what's also great about Kowloon? The prices for tasty bites that won't break the bank.
author: James Z.

description: I love going to Asian dessert places late at night to satisfy any sweet cravings. One of my favorite snacks is the thick toast with condensed milk. Unfortunately I was a bit disappointed with my order here. The toast was good but I would've loved to have more condensed milk over it. I also ordered the KT sandwich which wasn't too bad but I would not order it again. Overall as a spot that stays open pretty late, I would only come here if I had no other options to go to.
author: Joanne C.

description:
Below average experience...food was truly mediocre, and most likely won't be back. So many better places like Shooting Star Cafe in Oakland!

I ordered:

-egg puffs: batter is not great, no fragrant smell, comes out a tad burnt.
-brown sugar tofu fa: was so looking forward to this and so let down. came out with a huge chunk of brown sugar on top, and the brown sugar never melted so the tofu fa tasted super sandy and gritty. awful!
-sesame paste: way too creamy/milky, tastes like it came out of a package

wont be back.
author: Cynthia H.

description:
We came here for dessert on a Saturday night. It was pretty full and there was a list for the inside seating. We didn't want to wait so we just ordered to go.

The workers were not as friendly, more focus on customer service would be something to work on. $10 minimum charge for credit cards. The free ice cream waffle sandwich if you do the Yelp check in on your phone only works if you spend more than $40 and if you dine-in. Okay, pass then.

We only ordered the ice cream waffle sandwiches to go as a quick dessert snack. I probably wouldn't come here again. Parking is the usual street/meter parking. Do not park in the grocery parking lot.
author: Michael T.

description:
Actually i wanna give them 4stars BUT today i got a bad experience of their service, it was too slow since it really packed today. I would recommend them hire more staff for better and faster services. I have been a couple of Chinese dessert place to try "Jee Mha Whu"(black sesame paste) and i would say that their black sesame paste was OK , better than The Creation(on Geary) but blander than Sweet heart cafe(on Grant)  

Finally, i wont recommend to come here for dinner or your entree but it's a good one for dessert which are fresh and not too sweet!!!
author: Tiratiwan L.

description:
We came in at around 9 PM and there weren't many people probably because it was a Tuesday night. We had just eaten dinner, but were craving a cheaper option for dessert. We ordered the chicken wings and a black sesame dessert. I am not a big fan of black sesame in general so I didn't really like that but the chicken wings were pretty good. I have come here before but actually never eaten anything.

This is a good place to get a late night snack or dessert, but don't expect mind blowing food.
author: Allyson L.

description:
We (group of 7) came her for dessert for my friends birthday. Being a Tuesday evening , we found parking right in front which was nice (meter street parking  but we came after hours). 

When we arrived, all the tables were full inside. After waiting approximately 10 minutes, we were seated. The bathroom was located in the back and was relatively clean. No paper towels , just air dryer. 

Our waiter was funny and friendly. Service was a little slow , but I understand since he was pretty much the only one there in a full place. The menu is cool and has a lot of dessert choices on the front side and food choices on the other side. 

I decided to try the waffle sandwich with cookies and cream ice cream . It was very good and filling. Waffle wasn't too hard or soft and the ice cream was really good. 

We told the waiter it was our friends birthday so he brought out a lit candle in my waffle sandwich and the entire place sang happy birthday which was pretty cool! 

Overall, fun experience and would be down to try something else on the menu next time.
author: Eddy P.

description:
Visited this place a few months ago after a Giant's game and had a 5 star experience. We saw they had a check in deal for a free waffle ice cream sandwich, but you needed to spend $40. It wasn't easy to get to $40, but we got a bunch of dishes to take home. Desserts were good and service as well. The desserts I brought home were LOVED by all of the roommates.

Brought the roommates here this weekend, so they could check the place out. We were in a bit of time crunch so we ordered everything to go. Service was good and another Yelper checked in and we got another free waffle, however desserts were not as good this time. Nothing was seriously wrong, food just was not as good as we had remembered.
author: Chinh L.

description: this place is awesome!! Great food great tastes, very authentic candonse style, it's a mix of chinese cuisine and western cuisine. I love this restaurant, it is a mist try place when go to San Francisco
author: Will X.

description: Don't go here. Food doesn't taste like anything. The wait is so long. We came in and waited for a good 10-15mins. After ordering we waited for another 20 mins. When we finally gave up with our meal. We tried to get our check, that took 10-15mins just to get it. So please save save yourself from a bad experience with them.
author: Feevee O.

description: Love this place for the selection, hours, and service!  I like how they have a selection of savory and sweet items, and a lot of drinks.  The place is also open at convenient hours and with the amount of people it isn't too loud, crowded, and is always clean.  Prices aren't bad either and they have table service to avoid waiting in line.  The menu is a mix of Chinese, American, and some Japanese.  I always had good experiences with the employees and I come here usually in the late hours.
author: Lola S.

description:
went here after the Legion of Honor & De Young Museums free admission tour (first Tuesday of the month).
it was cloudy, cold and I was craving some warm desserts.
I had the curried fish ball (7/10) and warm black sticky rice with taro and coconut milk (9/10) Amazing!
I will definitely be back in the future to try other thing as much as possible from this cozy place.
author: Rudy H.

description:
Reference review for myself. 

Best sago I've had.

But.. if there's better.. I honestly wouldn't know.

It was good. Had the mango sago. It hits the spot.

If you were wondering what the difference between the mango and super mango sago.. the super mango has grapefruit in it.
author: Lilian L.

description:
My friends and I were looking for an alternative to a bar and came across Kowloon Tong Dessert Cafe (thanks, Yelp). We arrived around 10 pm and it was a FULL HOUSE! Make sure to put your name on the waiting list at the board (to your right when you enter). We waited about 15 minutes before being seated. Service was fast given the amount of orders going in at once. 

Don't be mistaken as Kowloon Tong serves up more than just dessert. They have soup, noodles, chicken wings (which smelled delicious) and many other savory treats! 

We ordered the ice cream waffle sandwich, which they kindly accommodated with two flavors. Green tea ice cream fell a bit short for me as it wasn't as potent as I'd preferred. The HK milk tea is a great alternative to their house tea. The Super Mango is another must have. It was full of flavor, made sure to cure that sweet tooth craving!
author: Sarin P.

description: First time in tonight. Super busy and I can understand why... it's the only place around that serves these types of Asian desserts. It didn't taste amazing or anything special to me. I probably wouldn't be back for the dessert unless my friends insist on going to hang out.
author: Linda L.

description:
Came here at 9PM on a Monday night, and saw some reviews saying service was slow. But it wasn't at all the case when we visited! We had a puppy with us and didn't want to leave him in the car and asked the owner if we can bring him in and just place him in his crate next to our feet. He said sure!! I couldn't believe it! It saved us so much trouble because we were worried about him being alone in the car. 

The food was alright for its price. I wish there was more condensed milk on the toast but other than that everything was cool.
author: Anna L.

description:
After having dinner in the area, we decided to walk to Kowloon Tong Dessert Cafe for dessert. We walked in on Saturday, December 3rd around 6:45pm. Only a couple of tables were taken, so we easily grabbed a table for four by the window.

*Super Mango Pudding ($6.95)
*Super B-Kid Grass Jelly ($7.50)
*Ice Cream Nutella Waffle Sandwich ($7.95)
*Mixed Fruits Coconut Milk Sago ($5.75)

I got the mango pudding. I liked that the dessert wasn't too sweet. The pudding was nice and creamy. The fruit on top was good except for the mango pieces. They were overly ripe and some had brown spots. Kinda put me off on the dessert, but I ate the rest of the fruit (minus the honeydew since I don't like most melons). The grass jelly in my girlfriend's dessert was good as well. Nice and silky. I also got a hot tea which wasn't on our bill, so I'm not sure if we get hot tea for free?

Nice place for Asian desserts. Though I do wish they did snow ice as I adore snow ice!
author: Elena N.

description: Always reliable, open late and good asian dessert. Love their Tofu Fa (only available on weekend) Not good for big group as the waiting time for table can be long. Small group of 2-4 ppl are good.
author: Dan A.

description:
Question: what's the damn service charge? I'm not sure if it's the SF health tax or if it's just their fee they charge. Plus it's around 20%

Food is okay and stay open late night.
author: Luis L.

description:
Bad customer service . 
We ordered the fresh coconut and it's come out so old. The coconut turned purple and smelly and I've informed her, she just keep saying is fine. I think it's fine to her because she is not drinking it .  Beside that the dessert tasted good.
author: Kelley T.

description:
Great place for a late night HK dessert. 

I had the mango sago one time and the mango go go the other. Both were similar in taste but very good.

My husband tried the waffle ice cream sandwich the first time. It was okay, but he mostly liked the Dreyer's ice cream. On the seco nd visit, he had the puffle, and he preferred that one much more. It seemed fresher, and he liked the texture better.
author: michelle l.

description:
I'm always on the lookout for late night Chinese dessert spots in the city, and was happy to come across Kowloon. 

We ordered a mixed fruit mango sago, spicy chicken wings, egg puffs, veggies with XO sauce, and glutinous rice balls with sesame paste. Service was quick and the food was just as we expected. I'll definitely be back to explore the rest of this extensive menu.

Much faster service than Golden Island.
author: Tim X.

description: Great place for Chinese dessert - from glutinous balls (different filling like sesame, peanuts) with different soup like red bean soup, almond milk and taro sago.  They also have cold dessert like fresh fruit sago, ice cream with waffles, etc. if you are hungry - they also have noodles, rice dishes that are good for a midnight snack.  One of our favorite places to get dessert around the Richmond district.
author: J Z.

description:
For a desert stop, this place is A-OK. The food here ranges from sandwiches, ramen, and snacks, to a full selection of desserts. Everything is fairly tasty, although a bit pricey for what you wind up getting. Few things that we ordered that I really recommend getting:

-Egg Puffs
-Plain Glutinous Rice Balls w/ Peanuts
-Spicy Popcorn Chicken

If you're going with a group or planning to just pig out, make sure to check into your Yelp app for a free Ice Cream Waffle (need to spend $40+). 

This is one of the best, late night food options around Richmond.
author: Alex C.

description:
Been here a few times and tried a few things on the menu. It's always busy here so make sure you put your name on the list. It's by the wall of gashapon machines.

Don't expect good service or any service for that matter. Every time we come here, we get the same few guys and they're rude. It also doesn't matter if you're speaking english or cantonese, they treat everyone the same except their "homies." At least it reminds me of HK.

Mango sago - It's okay. Similar to something you would get in HK. Depending on what night you go, the consistency tends to change. Sometimes the mangos are too ripe and it all oozes into a orange soup and sometimes the sago is overcooked so you can't even taste it. But it's good enough if you're craving it.

Egg puff - I will pass on this. Their eggpuffs aren't airy enough. It might be the batter or the process but when you bite into them they're chewy and hard. Also last time we ordered it, it took around 30 mins to make. Everyone else was done with their dessert. 

This place reminds me of a HK cha chan tang mixed with a dessert parlor. It's good enough to remind you of HK, but nothing will replace the real thing.
author: Junella T.

description:
Sad to say that this place did not meet any expectations during our visit here. It was enough for us to not come back anytime in the near future. 

Came in on a Friday evening with a friend and we decided to try this place since we've both already tried other Asian dessert places in the area. As soon as we walked in we noticed that the place was pretty packed. Glad we made it in before the rush because we noticed groups forming in the waiting room area as we were deciding. Since we just ate dinner, we were only concentrating on the dessert menu. There were so many options, we were a little overwhelmed deciding. There were photos which made the process easier, but most of them didn't. There's also no descriptions so we tried to figure out what a certain dish was. After we told the server that we needed an extra minute to decide, he didn't come back until we waved him down almost 10 minutes later. Took us numerous tries to get his attention as well. 

After the long and indecisive process, we decided to get the Super mango-go-go to share between the two of us. The man who brought it out gave us a regular mango-go-go. As he turned away we told him we ordered the super. He gave us the super mango-go-go in his other hand and took away the regular one. Finally, we were excited to dig right in! First bite, bits of little sago and ..... ice? Frozen sago? We were both taken by surprise when we tasted it and spent a while trying to figure out why there were random frozen bits in it. Seemed like it was just frozen sago at the bottom. Moving on, we each ate a mango piece and it honestly tasted like bland stringy fibers. I love mangoes too! What a disappointment. My friend mentioned that the best part of the dish was probably the mango ice cream since you already expect the artificial flavoring in it. 

Since there were still people waiting, we tried to wave down the waiter again so we could get the check. After a couple unsuccessful tries, the cashier notices us and comes over. We ask for the check and she brings us a check. Except, it was the wrong check. Now we had to wave her down again to ask for the correct check. Overall, there were too many mistakes made for a simple order. The dish itself was subpar and we felt like we were playing a guessing game with each bite.
author: Nancy C.

description:
After eating way too much at an AYCE place nearby, we decided to take a walk to walk off the food. And what did we find on our walk? More food. I know, we shouldn't have stopped but we walked into Kowloon Tong Dessert Cafe and decided to have some dessert.

I'm not familiar with Asian desserts and after browsing the Yelp photos, I decided to get the Ice Cream Puffle. It turned out to be a great choice. The "balls" of the egg waffle had a good amount of stretchiness while still maintaining some crunchiness in the thin portion. The waffle was served with two scoops of ice cream: strawberry and green tea. The ice cream flavors were a bit more artificial than the fancy ice cream I'm used to after living in SF for so long.

It was a pleasant stop and I wish we could've eaten more but my date doesn't really eat sweets and I basically ate most of it myself. I wouldn't come out of the way for this place but it's not a bad choice if you're already in the area.
author: Yi Z.

description:
We come here often for the hk desserts and I finally got to try their sweet tofu (dou fu fa in Cantonese). Yay!!! They use brown sugar for sweetness topped over the Silky tofu. It's pretty good although I think smile cafe on Taraval is better. 

Besides their sweet desserts they have rice plates and lots of savory snacks, perfect when I'm in the mood for Hk style food. 

This place typically gets crowded in the evening but the wait isn't too bad, most of the time. Parking can be difficult depending on the time. Don't expect top notch service, as with any other Chinese restaurant, but you can expect efficiency. 

Prices are reasonable, if you order the rice plates I It come with a drink. for an extra $2 you can get either sesame paste, sweet tofu, mango pudding or turtle jelly. Our bill for 5 people and 1 rice plate take out came out to be $90.
author: W W.

description:
Came back here after the Warriors win. The place was pretty empty but it still took awhile to get 4 desserts - 2 waffle ice cream sandwiches and 2 sagos after 10pm. 

Perhaps I'm partial to Golden Island...and Creations even. Everything was sort of bland.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Great service, ambiance is roomy and comfortable. We came in for some dessert and enjoyed a mango-go-go and some some hot hk tea . The fresh mangoes and fresh grapefruit combined with the milky sago was surprisingly delicious and totally satiated our sweet tooth. The tea was also yummy. This place gets busy but is casual and great for groups and families.
author: Roshni S.

description:
This place's boba drink isn't good.  My spouse and I both took a sip and that was it. We couldn't drink much further because it tasted so badly.

The pork chop noodle is simple and not worth the price. The bowl is basically filled with bland soup with a small piece of broccoli and a piece of meat on top.

The only thing we like is the black sesame and almond paste dessert.

The service was bad and food are pricey. We'll never come back again or recommend this place to anyone.
author: Analysi S.

description: The fruit used for the ice cream sundae wasn't ripe at all but the French toast was tasty and as expected.
author: Shelton F.

description:
This is a place where i always go at the late night, I have been working late⋯ This Cafe could be my most favor cafe!!-！:)

FOOD：

Environment：ALWAYS crowded

PRICE：$-$$ Cheap

BEST SUGGETION：WINGS!!!
author: Yingying C.

description: The food is decent and when we ask for the check, this place will charge you more than 20 percent for service charge.
author: Justin H.

description:
I looove Kowloon haha. This is my go to dessert/ late night snack / drunchies spot! I like it over the other late night dessert places because they have more choices and yummier savory snacks. Don't expect fancy tables, chairs, etc. everything is pretty worn and dishes are plasticky but it's ok the food is cheap and good. 

I normally get the salt & pepper wings. They are so so so good! Comes with garlic and onions on top of juicy fat wings. They are on the oily side but it's so worth the extra mile you might have to run the next day. 

I also really like the stir fry ramen with pickled cabbage and pork. Super unhealthy but also very good! Great drunchies food ^____^ Their sago desserts and grass jelly desserts are very refreshing, not too sweet/ syrupy. 

Service isn't spectacular, but they are never rude and I've never had a problem. There's a good amount of parking on Geary late at night.
author: Nancy C.

description: I think this is the only dessert shop outside of the Chinatown area in San Francisco. The cafe has plenty of seating and their menu is extensive. You can order both savory and sweet foods. We ordered the egg puffs, black sesame pudding, and almond pudding. All of it was delicious. I think there was only one person working here so the service was a bit slow but I was thankful our food was brought out to us nice and hot.  I thought some of the prices were on the high side but this is the only place around that serves these types of dishes so I guess its justified.
author: Janet E.

description: A solid 4 stars I've been coming here lately to get my mango sago fix lol..there egg puff are pretty good nothing like Hong Kong or Taiwan but hey it will do...it can get busy so plan to wait if your coming after 8pm
author: jonathan h.

description:
In the past, I've been here and I loved this place, especially since it has authentic Hong Kong desserts. My experience this time around sucked, but honestly it could be possible that they were so busy Saturday evening that everything was rushedly prepared? Saturday evenings at 9, expect a twenty minute wait.

We ordered all of our drinks and menu items at once, but we didn't receive our drinks till around 30 minutes later with all of our food. We ordered an eggpuff, which was already cold when we received it (it was such a disappointment)! We also ordered red green bean paste soup and to fu fa with brown sugar. Both were very mediocre.
author: Kristen L.

description:
Well deserved this one star review from me. 

1. My first bite on the rice noodles: THERE ARE ROCKS IN IT! Isn't it ridiculous?  There's definitely something wrong with their food quality. That piece of rice noodle really hurt my teeth with the rocks in it. So watch out for that if you insist to order that dish. 

2. What really made m so mad: the way that they handle this issue. After I mentioned this problem, the people who worked here all heard about it, since I was sitting right next to the cashier. With no apologies, they asked if I want to cancel or get a new one. I told them to cancel, and they did. I'm just so shocked about their ignorance of their customers. Nobody even paid any attention to us. 
This is absurd. 

3. I talked to them. I told them they should really pay attention to the food safety. Two of the three servers just pretend like they didn't see me. One of them told me the rice noodle is from their vendor. It's originally like that. Excuse me? Your restaurant is serving the food to me, and should me 100% responsible for the food. So do you expect me to complain about this to your rice noodle vendor? 

No apologies made to me. No discount offered. They just don't care. Ruined my night, not coming back. Will share this experience with people around me. Sorry I still need to concern about FOOD SAFETY AND CUSTOMER SERVICE. This place won't get business from me again.
author: Evelyn W.

description:
I came here with some friends after a late movie since it was one of the very few dessert places open past midnight. The crazy thing is, even at 1am the place was completely full and we still had to wait to get seated. SF, it's like no matter what I can't escape the lines.... qq. 

We got completely suckered into trying to spend over $40 to redeem the free waffle ice cream sandwich check-in deal, and even though it left me stuffed, I think it was totally worth it. I got the almond tofu fa and a watermelon juice. Both tasted delicious and exactly how you expect them to at any asian dessert cafe. The waffle ice cream sandwich was, when they served it to us, looked kind of underwhelming to me, especially since I had just finished my other two items and was pretty full. It ended up tasting surprisingly delicious though- I think because they might have used the same batter that they use for the egg puffs. Will def come back if I'm ever in the area again or in need of a late night dessert!
author: Stephany L.

description:
This restaurant is crazily busy even late at night. It certainly has the atmosphere of Hong Kong. The menu offers wide variety of dessert choices. They even has appetizer options but we didn't order them. We wanted to use the Yelp coupon for a free ice cream waffle. But we would have to spend over $40 to redeem the coupon which is just too hard. 

We ended up ordering couple dishes to try. The ginger stemmed milk had good flavor but it was too wet. The mango sago was not too exciting. The best dish was the mango pudding. Excellent mango pudding with 2 scoops of mango ice cream filled with fresh fruit. Be warned that it is cash only! Service was good but crazy.
author: Karen W.

description:
Mmm, HK-styled desserts!!

We came around 10pm on a Thursday night and were seated immediately. My main intention of going here was to order some desserts because I was craving, and the ice cream with egg puffs looked so good! When the waitress came over to take our order though, we ended up ordering the curry fish balls too because the table next to us had ordered it, and it smelled DELICIOUS.

Neither of the dishes disappointed! The fish curry balls came out first, and my friend and I practically devoured it in seconds, AND we kept trying to somehow eat the curry after we had already finished the balls. For the ice cream with egg puffs, I think the egg puffs stood out the most. It was so fluffy on the inside yet perfectly golden on the outside. (I'm not sure if that's how you correctly describe egg puffs.. but it was better than any of the other ones I've tried!!)

Ambience is kind of typical of an Asian restaurant - nothing too fancy. Their service is also ok, but they have decently priced food, and they're open late so you can't go wrong with that!
author: Tricia N.

description: If you like HK style desert, this would be the place. Great selections of sago, glutinous dumplings and bean soups.
author: Michael W.

description:
After a few hours of walking around California Academy of Sciences, we decided to look for a nearby place for an afternoon snack.  Yelp led us to Kowloon Tong, located on the corner of 7th and Geary.  Of course, we were targeting HK-style desserts!

Egg Puffs were hot with crispy outside and soft and pillowy inside. It wasn't super sweet, which is a good thing. 4 stars.

Black Sesame soup with black-sesame filled glutinous balls - Excellent dish, but it tends to be slighty sweeter than other places.  I liked how the glutinous balls had a granular sweet black sesame filling so you get some nice texture contrast too. 4 stars.

Taro with coconut milk and sweet rice - I got this dish cold and it was pretty light and refreshing.  4 stars.

Overall we like this place - about the same quality as Golden Island over in Noriega St but here both the dessert menu and savory snack menu seem larger.  I would consider coming back if I'm in the area.
author: Daniel C.

description: This place has the best deserts ever! If you want authentic Chinese dessert, I recommend that you come to this place. It's always busy so I recommend not coming during the weekends or at night. You won't be able to find a seat. Service is fast though because they have a lot of customers. It's just that customers tend to just sit there and hang out when they're done with their dessert.
author: Nancy T.

description:
EGG PUFF. Enough said.

Yay for yummy Asian desserts - all your favorite Canto/TW desserts on deck, dessert soups (tong yuen - lots of flavors, xi mi, etc.), condensed milk toast, waffle green tea ice cream sandwich is YUM (enough to share 2-4),HK milk tea, mango sago...

Table next to us was happily enjoying popcorn chicken and other street eats.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
This place is an option for you when you're craving a late night dessert in the city.

 But make sure you have a lot of patience because the wait is awful. My other problem with this place would be the horrible customer service. It takes forever to get your food because of the workers lack of interest in taking your order. 

I got their Ice Cream Waffle Sandwich (Green Tea) which was basically a waffle sandwich with your choice of ice cream flavor inside. It was decent, nothing too special. It got a little messy after awhile which I didn't like. There are other flavors such as: mango, strawberry, vanilla, chocolate and cookies and cream. 

I'm not too crazy about this place, there are probably other places that'll make your experience more enjoyable.
author: Breanna N.

description:
extremely long 25 minute wait for a very simple takeout order.  nobody else was in line.  The dessert we ordered was very easy to make, but the staff member just was not considerate we were waiting, and was simply talking on the phone. We assumed that she was waiting for the dessert to heat up or be prepared, but this was not the case. Once we pressed her that we needed to receive our dessert or get a refund, she walked over and prepared our dessert in 10 seconds. It was clear that we were waiting, but were ignored.

The dessert itself was okay.
author: Jimming C.

description:
Decent dessert! The mango a go go came with pomelo, mango, and sago. Regular is enough to split between two people if you're kind of full but still have some room for dessert. 

Also, it's actually open late, thank you for saving people who like to be awake past 9.
author: Connie L.

description: There are many similar cafes like this one, where they offer a bunch of Chinese comfort food as well as a variety of desserts. I usually lean towards these types as it gives me a ton of options to choose from. The customer service here was great, our server was friendly and nice. The food came quickly and was as expected. The desserts that we got looked amazing and tasted good as well. Would definitely come back again. The only downside is that it's a bit small, but there was plenty of seating.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Ordered the mango-go-go and peanut glutinous balls w/ crushed peanuts to share with my friend. The mango was especially sweet,tasted very fresh and each spoonful of the dessert was refreshing and thirst quenching. The peanut glutinous balls were bite size and a pleasure to eat. 

The atmosphere here was lively, yet quiet enough to hold a conversation. One huge plus, was that this place opens late even on a Sunday night when lots of other boba/dessert places close down.
author: Edward W.

description: I love this place! Perfect for a late night meal and pick me up snack. They always quench my cravings whether sweet or savory...its so good! Definitely one of my favorite go-tos in sf
author: Sarah R.

description: Beautiful Service. The food was amazing and the food was great. Its a great place for a hangout spot!!!
author: Linus N.

description:
I've been coming to Kowloon for a couple years now and it's always been the same. The food is very comforting but the service is a hit or miss. Obviously when it's emptier there is better service but I've also been here when it's super crowded and the servers don't even look at you. This place is definitely one of those places where friends just hang out and talk. There's nothing amazing about this place but it's exactly what you need when you want it. 
I always get the spicy instant noodles with the salt and pepper chicken. It's exactly what it sounds like. They just put some sesame oil into instant noodles. To spicy it up I take the garlic from the chicken wings and put it into the soup for extra flare. Lol
I also like the mixed fruit sago just because I like the different fruit but there is still nothing special about it too. I just always seem to come back here because I feel like whatever is on the menu is exactly what it sounds like. No surprises
author: Ada N.

description: It is an OK Hong Kong style dessert place. If you want treats that are not super sweet. This is the place!
author: Emmy P.

description:
After visiting Schubert's bakery, we drove past Kowloon Tong Dessert Café which piqued my parents' interests as they're pretty serious about their Hong Kong desserts. We came back at night with the intention to just eat a small snack, but we ended up eating dinner and dessert.

There's a ton of street parking if you go during the night. We avoided the late night crowd when we got here around 8 on a Friday night. Pretty soon there was a long list of people waiting for seats at the café. A lot of young adults/teenagers seem to frequent this place, buying desserts and chatting with each other, so I'd recommend coming a little earlier to avoid the crowd. 

The menu is extensive. There are so many different dessert items that it took us quite awhile before we figured out what to order. From noodles to sago to milkshakes, they have pretty much all the essential Hong Kong desserts you can think of. 

Dessert Items: 

Mixed Fruit Sago w/ Condensed Milk: I just wanted to get a dessert item, and thought this sounded fairly good. It was underwhelming and definitely not what I was expecting. I think I could probably throw this concoction together at home. There were various fruits on top of the condensed milk, but nothing special. The condensed milk was sweet and the sago was chewy enough, but it pretty much tasted like a typical dessert you'd get at the end of a meal at a Chinese restaurant. I would not order this again. 

Black Sesame Dessert: This was part of the daily special - I thought it tasted okay. It had a strong sesame flavor, which is preferred, but this dessert isn't a favorite of mine, so I can't really give a fair review. My parents thought it tasted pretty good, although I think they've had better from Premiere Dessert back in LA. 

Egg Waffles: Our waffles were a little burnt, so they came out crispy rather than soft. I actually prefer crispy, but the batter had no taste to it, so it was kind of like eating crispy crackers. The inside was pretty soft, but without the sweetness that it needs, it wasn't too good. 

Complimentary Ice Cream Waffles: If you spend over $30, they give you a free ice cream waffle dish, which my mom was set on trying. And I'm glad we did because this was probably the best thing I had here! They serve real Dreyer's ice cream, so they placed a thick scoop of vanilla ice cream in between two crispy waffles. It came out well. Because the batter is not sweet (probably the same batter as the Egg Waffle batter), the ice cream from the center really gives the entire bite the sweetness that I craved. The crispiness of the waffles and the softness of the ice cream really worked for me. 

Horlick Drink: This came with the daily special as well. The drink was okay. My parents really like the drink because it reminds them of their childhood days. There was good flavor, but I'm not a fan. 

Savory Dishes:

Curry Fish Balls: There were 8 fish balls altogether. While the fish balls weren't too special - they tasted as if they were frozen beforehand - the curry did taste really good. It wasn't too spicy, but had a good earthy flavor to it that made me want to add rice to it. Not too bad. 

Imitation Shark Fin Soup: $4.25 It was decent, but definitely had better in HK. Even HK's 7/11's have better tasting (and cheaper) imitation shark fin soup! I thought this one tasted too salty. There was a decent amount of ingredients inside, but the saltiness of the soup overpowered everything. 

Soya Chicken Wings with Vermicelli: $6.50 I thought this was a pretty decent dish considering the price. There were three chicken wings with a pretty big bowl of vermicelli. It was enough to fill my sister and me up. The dish took around 15 minutes to cook, and it was well worth the time because the chicken wings had good flavor that really soaked through beyond the skin of the chicken. The soup base was not too heavy and was quite light, which was nice. 

Chicken and Pork daily special: This was $9.50 plus an additional $1.95. I thought the price was a little expensive considering the tiny pieces of chicken and pork that came with the dish. You're able to pick your choice of sauce, rice or spaghetti, one hot drink, and a dessert (additional $2). So overall this dish was over $13. There was a good amount of rice (which we used to soak up the curry sauce) as well as a small scoop of corn. The chicken and pork were cooked well and the skin had that crispy perfection to it. I just thought they were quite small. 

tl;dr - Overall, I thought it was a decent place to have dinner. It's reminiscent of Hong Kong, but doesn't really come close to the authenticity of HK's desserts and food. I would come back again for the ice cream waffle! There are actually a few other HK dessert stores within a few blocks of this one, but this was the most crowded.
author: Tiffany C.

description: I was dared to write a review about the difference between gluten and non-glutenous and I'm extremely salty. So I'm going to say the difference is that gluten means you can tolerate their existence where as non-glutenous is people that you avoid like the plague. Feel free to correct me. Also the dessert was good.
author: Larry T.

description: Love coming here for late night snacks or even a meal. They mostly serve Hong Kong desserts. It gets crowded late at night, so be aware that you might have to wait. The service is nice and the food/desserts are well priced.
author: Tamara L.

description:
I went there when they just opened at 5 p.m. last time and today I went at 9ish. The waiter was so nice. The service was great!!
The food was just okay.. but the place is cheap and a to go place for hang out at night.
author: Candice L.

description:
I visited at night, 12:00 am. I ordered for to-go. They served the worst coffee/w condensed milk. It was not strong enough, and the taste was like oolong milk tea. 

And, the chocolate egg puff was not fully cooked, and the shape was really massy. Very disappointed.
author: Seung H.

description:
Large menu with a variety of different drinks and snacks, but so-so quality. 

Egg puff- average. The shells aren't crunchy enough,and the puffs are pretty dense. Disappointing.

Green tea ice cream waffle- The waffles are average, ice cream is also average too. Great portion though, definitely need to share with friends!

Salt and spicy pepper chicken wing- The flavoring is separate from the chicken wings. The wings are fresh and well-fried, the meat is so tender! However, the salt and pepper is just sprinkle on top and do not integrate with the wings. I wish the wings are better seasoned!

Great place to hang out in the Richmond district, spacious and cheap, but there are other better Hong Kong style dessert cafes!
author: Karen C.

description: We came in on a Saturday night and it was packed, so we decided to get it Togo instead. The menu was huge they had a lot of food and desserts to choose from. I ordered the spam and egg sandwich which was pretty good, cause I mean you can't go wrong with that. Then we also got the curry fish ball which I didn't really like because it tasted weird like the the fish ball texture was kind of weird and the curry tasted like a mix of curry and peanut paste or something. The egg puff wasn't all that either because I like mines kinda with a chewy texture but this was really bready and lacked sweetness. The steamed milk pudding was good, it was smooth and silky and really flavored well. The service was good but I think the inconsistency with the food may be because of how busy they were. Overall it was okay, I'll probably try again when they aren't super packed.
author: Maybeline C.

description:
Basically, there were no other places open at 1:15 AM. So that leads to the reason why My boyfriend and I decided to come here. Off the bat, it was busy. We tried to order but there seems to be only two staff. One on the cashier and one serving (but to be honest, they were both just running around). There was no line and we probably waited like a good minute to order but as soon as we tried to order literally we kept getting interrupted because the cashier guy kept getting distracted.. 
anyways, we finished ordering and I kid you not we waited like 40 minutes for CHICKEN WINGS/FRIES & FRIED SQUID BALLS. I get that it was a little busy but damn??
We finally got our food and opened it in the car. They gave us the wrong order... they gave us some meat with rice and corn instead of chicken wings & fries. I looked at my order which was the Fried squid balls ($4.75 btw) it was only 6 pieces.. way too greasy and didn't taste that good for the price LOL.
My boyfriend then came back to get the right order, we waited for like a good 15 minutes LOL. But He said the chicken wings tasted pretty good so there's the reason why I gave it two stars but the fries were really unseasoned..
If it's not 1:10 in the morning, and there's several places to go. I personally suggest to go to other places because this place was pretty whack.
author: Tanya D.

description: The desserts here are awesome, service can be a little confusing though and it gets packed, surprisingly! Kind of a hole in the wall in terms of location but the place itself accommodates groups. The menu is huge so it's kind of overwhelming, definitely refer to suggestions from yelp if u can't decide!
author: Yasmeen S.

description: Been here quite a few times with friends and overall, the visits have been pretty average/mediocre. Depending on what time you come, the place can be completely filled and have long lines (usually at night) or practically empty (early evening). The 3 stars are an average rating of all the food/snacks/desserts I've tried here; the mango-go-go is great if you love mango and coconut milk. The mango is crazy sweet and delicious. The "popcorn chicken" on the other hand, not so much. The batter tasted like it was a few days old, although they just opened shop and we were the first customers. The red bean with shaved ice was literally shaved ice with red beans on top...had the ice cream sundae with waffles a few times and well, you can never go wrong with ice cream.
author: Joanne H.

description: Salt&Hot Pepper Chicken Wings,I don't like it,This restaurant tasted so so ,Curry Fishballs i won't eat next time in here
author: Stephanie M.

description: Waited too long for the dessert. Ordered a almond sweet soup & sesame sweet soup. Almond soup came in around 10 mins, sesame one was just wait too long. Like 20-30 mins  food was ok, service was ok. Bill was ~$10.
author: Jasmine S.

description: Ordered the black sesame paste with black sesame balls. I agree with other reviews that the paste here is watery and a bit too sweet (in addition, you can't even request for it to be less sweet.) Prices here are higher than other Chinese dessert places in the area too, for similar quality dessert.
author: Christine L.

description:
basically 5 things to sum up the experience: 

1. asian af: issa niche

2. a range of simple, not-too-sweet, hot and cold desserts. the tofu fa, mango sago, grass jelly fruit bowls, and waffle ice-cream sandwiches were all solid--esp the waffle ice-cream sandwich (they use egg puff batter i think so its chewy and yummy). they also serve some rice meals and appetizers ( not strongly flavored and very simple)

3. fresh pressed juice is a really good call

4. crowded at 1am on a saturday so service can be slow but at least you know they are trying their best to be fast ( unlike some places)

5. vibe: not dimlit and not too loud; tons of small couple tables that are rearranged for larger groups
author: Lydia Z.

description: Extremely let down. Ordered mixed fruit sago and it wasn't sweet at all. Once the fruit is gone it tastes like a spoon of water with mini balls. No thickness, very watered down. Egg puffs barely any chocolate
author: Thien T.

description:
Surprisingly packed on a Sunday night ~9-10PM! It's in a pretty quiet neighborhood and is easy to miss (it's tucked around the corner from the larger street). Overall if you're in the neighborhood you could stop by but I would rather go elsewhere for a sugary bite.

Ambiance: Very typical asian dessert bar - pretty loud and a little messy. Opens till pretty late and has a pretty wide variety!

Food: black sesame balls - overpriced for what it is 
Matcha green tea waffle ice cream sandwich: the green tea flavor wasn't super strong and was too sugary for my taste. However, this is a random tiny dessert bar so I kindof expected as much?
author: Taryn Q.

description:
Cheap, delicious, and authentic. 

I highly recommend the soy sauce chicken wings, egg puffs, and mango sago. 
Unfortunately, I didn't get to try the Tofu Fa because they ran out- but I'll be back for that. (;

Service: prompt, short, and curt service. Its like any typical small HK cafe. 

A note-- I've heard from friends that sometimes the fried food can be inconsistent, the fried tofu was good some days and bad others. Be wary.
author: Maggie Y.

description: Always love coming here for mate night dessert! The staff is not super attentive, the area is pretty loud with all the patrons talking, and the chairs/tables aren't the most comfortable, but it's a great place to come hang out with friends and grab some food. I always come here with a lot of friends and they are ver accommodating of large groups. Late night snack? Check. Asian dessert? Check. Hot and cold drinks? Check!
author: Anna Y.

description:
My brother and i came here after the zoo. We were thinking to get the free check in ice cream waffle sandwich with other dessert when we saw the free ice cream waffle in yelp app. But we didnt realize that we had to spend about $30 to get it. We got 4 items but it wasnt enough anyways. We came 10 minutes after it was open. People started rolling in after 30 minutes. While we were waiting for our dessert, my brother and i heard sneezing and look at each other and wasnt sure what to do. It was disgusting to hear it from the kitchen area but Couldnt do nothing about it since we already order it.  and wasnt sure if anyone else heard it before it got a little crowded. Lost a star after hearing the sneeze. I would give them 3 stars if i didnt hear it

Service was okay. Kinda slow to bring out the dessert after ordering

Here are the desserts that we got:

Super mango go go
Salt and pepper chicken wings
Egg puffs
Mixed fruit sago

Some were average while others were good. The price are reasonable
author: Julie N.

description:
This place is LIT@@@ it's got sugar, it's got hype, it's got late hours, what else can you ask for? This place was packed when our group of 5 got here. It took ~15 minutes for them to seat us, which is pretty fast according to my friend. They have a very large selection of Hong Kong food and desserts; a lot of times you can't find anywhere else because it's so authentic. 

Nutella ice cream waffle sandwich - 5/5 my favorite dessert by far!
Black sesame egg waffle - 2/5 it tasted like regular egg waffle and the "filling" was just tasteless black sesame seeds on the outside of the waffle
Red bean gluttonous rice ball - 4/5 so good, but a bit pricey imo
Super mango go-go - 3/5 the ice cream was the best part, the rest of the dish was a little flavorless
author: Jingting W.

description:
Kowloon Tong is a staple in late night, dessert craving, hanging with friends, random turn of events spot to hit up.

I remember this place being around since my high school days and not much has changed.

You still can get your fix of traditional, hk/canto style desserts. Items range from hot milk teas, to mango sago, hot tofu fa, eggettes, and numerous other assortment of items.

The place is usually pretty packed, even on weeknights. Items come out quickly and though it's not the fanciest of places, the desserts are yummy. Quality wise, meh, but you're trying to grab dessert at like 10pm, your choice in SF are limited.

I've always had a positive experience here. Wait staff are nice.

Some staples that i enjoy are the following: glutonous rice balls filled with sesame, tofufa, mango sago, the super b kid mango item looks amazing.

Essentially you get your fix of either warm or cold asian desserts all in one place.
author: Diane T.

description:
this place is good, but it's never my first choice. I much prefer 100% and creations over this place, simply based on the desserts that they offer.

Kowloon has more tradition desserts, including tortoise shell jelly and stewed birds nest, and a smaller variety for sagos. The service was good. Our server came by and helped us with the many questions that we had. A note is that the menu isn't very descriptive at all. So I had no idea the difference a mango madness and a mango go-go. 

I ended up ordering something warm, tofu fa with brown sugar. I'm VERY happy that they didn't mix it together because it was WAY too much brown sugar. I scooped out more than half and it was still too sweet. Even though it was too sweet, I still enjoyed the texture of the tofu fa. Note: they only carry this dessert on certain days of the week (I believe only the weekends). 

If my friends were to suggest to come here, I wouldn't oppose and I would eat and enjoy; but unfortunately, based on my tastebuds and dessert preferences, it would not be my main choice for dessert cafes.
author: Tina Y.

description:
Ice cream waffle sandwich is the shit. I always ask what flavor ice cream they have for the day, cause they do switch it up daily... but most recently, I got cookies and cream mmmmmmmmm, so good. Besides this, depending on what I'm in the mood for, I get the peanut filled glutinous balls or just regular mango or strawberry sago. They have a pretty big menu in terms of dessert and if you flip it over you can actually order real food. I haven't tried anything on the food side besides chicken wings and fries, but probably cause I usually come late at night when I've already eaten dinner. 

The only downside is that they do get pretty packed sometimes, and they do take awhile serving the food (but I guess that means its fresh right?... hopefully. lol) One huge upside is that they take card! I've noticed that a lot of asian dessert places are cash only... which is pretty inconvenient sometimes.. but kowloon is changin the game!
author: Carrie L.

description:
I had the egg puff with ice cream it tastes pretty good and it's the authentic one that are half hollow and half solid with some uncooked batter inside. 
I also had the red bean shaved ice drink, which tasted pretty good too, but the one I had in china has an ice cream ball in it but this one doesn't. So I just moved one of the ice cream ball from the egg puff to the drink, then it's perfect. Will defiantly come back to this place again.
author: Berry P.

description:
Review Update

I am very glad I had an opportunity to be able to come back to this place. 

Review by GC

The menu is the size of a table placemat and is double sided. One side is full of hot food offerings including appetizers, meals and daily specials. The other side has all the dessert offerings which include hot and cold drinks as well as their signature ice cream creations. 

Review by GC

It looked jam packed inside but I spied a few empty seats.  It was quite fortunate since it was a Saturday evening. 

Review by GC

Some special mentions for the serving staff due to the outstanding service I received from the two awesome female servers:

When I walked in a friendly and polite female server happened to be near the door and I was seated immediately near the register area. She had shoulder length dark hair tied back and she had a very intricate tattoo design on her back. 

Review by GC

After looking through the menu another attentive and friendly server came to take my order. She had long flowing blond hair and helped to clarify a few things on the menu as well as made some recommendations. Her name started with a V (it was a very unique name that sounded difficult to spell). 

Review by GC

The place was busy when I walked in and there was a steady flow of customers going in and out for the duration of my stay. In addition to the two female servers there was a gentleman who was helping with tables. Between the three of them working together they were very prompt with getting all the orders and out as well as clearing the tables as well as handling the walk in customers taking the food to go. 

Review by GC

I ordered quite a few things to eat there which included favorites like the pork chops over white rice as an entree and the mixed fruit salad to start. I kept the menu close by because there were a few other items I wanted to try out. 

Review by GC

I got some props from one the servers when I added more food to the order. It was a comical situation but I was very famished and wanted to try different dishes. 

Review by GC

Some takeaways - good selection of hot and cold items so it makes for a nice place to have a meal or you can just order dessert, service was prompt and courteous for my visit, the size of the establishment is larger compared to other dessert shops or bars and prices are reasonable for the drinks, dishes and desserts. The kitchen staff and servers work very well together to make sure all the orders are brought out in a timely manner. The staff is fluent in English as well as Cantonese and Mandarin dialects. 

Review by GC

I am reminded why this is one of my favorite places in San Francisco to go eat and I look forward to the next meal there.
author: Gregory C.

description: good desserts. similar to desserts in Hong Kong. Would recommend getting desserts only because I've heard that most of the desserts are better than other foods they have.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I had a really fun time here. We came after dinner to grab desserts. They have a variety of different asian desserts, but they have regular food too. It smelled pretty awesome, so I want to try to come back another day for regular food. 

I Got the mango tapioca dish. It was good! And my friend got a dessert in a shape of a ying yang. 

It gets packed at night because everyone is coming here for desserts. Gets a little loud, but great vibe. Very cool place to hang out with friends.
author: Jackie N.

description: Amazing dessert selections. Only if it weren't so far I would have gotten to indulge in it more.
author: Valerie U.

description: I'm the only one here and I'm still waiting on my desserts. I asked about it and finally gave me my dessert in literally a minute- start to finish to make. So what the hell was she doing the entire time??? Pissed. Not even worth it.
author: Krystle L.

description:
i love sharing the chicken wings with my friends 

so oily so good

they have free ice cream only when you spend $40+
author: Stephen C.

description: It's a nice neighborhood spot with some delicious traditional Chinese deserts! The staff was very friendly and attentive. We tried two items on the menu but wanted to try more but our stomaches were too full.
author: Dak L.

description:
Great quick snack restaurant for your canto cravings!

I was craving some HK style egg puffs and found this place.  Decided to order the egg puffs, steamed rice rolls, and a milk tea.  The egg puffs are delicious!  Super crispy and light, i wish it has a little more egg flavor, but really good and just as good as the egg puffs in Hong Kong.  Definitely a most order!  

The steamed rolls are also excellent, served with  hoisin and peanut sauce.  These are better than a lot of dim sum places, another must try dish if you want some noodles rolls.  The milk tea is good too, but not amazing, it needed a stronger tea flavor.

Overall, a amazing canto style snack place, they offer a lot of variety and i will definitely be back to try more!
author: Terence N.

description: No star needed for this place, but since I have to one star it is. The service just beyond awful, took them 10 minutes to take our order and made us wait for more than 20 minutes after that to just tell us they lost our order and would like to take it again. Thanks for wasting our time for nothing!
author: Indira W.

description: My top go-to dessert spot in the area so far. Mango sago, rice roll, and chicken wings and fries were all pretty good and proportional. The mango was not sour and I loved the sago. We were able to split the appetizers among the 3 of us. Customer service can be iffy and they do get busy with a line forming at the entrance after 9PM even on a rainy day which was my case.
author: Donna M.

description: Woah! Came here to kill time and it was soooooo good! I didn't know what to order since they have a million things on the menu but all in all , I will definitely come back!
author: Lauren K.

description: A very casual late night experience. Even at 12AM it was busy. My friend ordered a bubble waffle and it was really good and chewy. My boyfriend and I ordered a mango sago and a super mango pudding. My mango pudding was okay, not the best thing I've ever tasted. But the mango sago is a must! It had an authentic taste of mango and was the most delicious mango sago that I've had so far!
author: Melissa L.

description: Ahhhhhhh yesssss ... this little hip place has it's merits. Great little place to hang out with friends to just chit chat and pick up something sweet at night. The seating area is always full and sometimes waiting for a seat can be a pain when it's cold outside. But all in all, a very good place to chill when it's late.
author: Patrick L.

description: Anazzzing desert place! Open late and super cool staff. Can not get any better! Pricing is right and lots of comfortable seat! FYI it can get really busy on weekends! Great Asian desert spot! Strongly recommended!
author: IHeartMambo S.

description: Always my togo late night asian desert place! My family and I always comes here. We get everything from their sagos, HK milk tea, egg puffs and glutinous balls. Everything is good here. Even their savory dishes, like popcorn chicken, and garlic fries. Nothing is too sweet.
author: Janet C.

description:
Yesss I've been here twice in the past few days and I'm loving this place. I first discovered this place as an Asian dessert cafe and everything looked super yummy so I knew that I needed to give it a try. My friend and I came on a Friday night and it was pretty packed actually. I got the Mango sago and he got a brown sugar doufuhua which apparently is quite hard to find--well, good doufuhua is at least. 

Mango sago was originally not sweet enough for me, but one I actually started to mix it, it started to taste a lot better. I've never had doufuhua before so this was a great introduction to it. The doufu itself was great consistency but the brown sugar was a little too strong and made the dish a little more difficult to have.

Anyways, as we were there though, I realized that they have a ton of good savory dishes too! Such a good typical HK style cafe. 

I got the instant noodles with pickled cabbage and sliced pork which was quite good. I mean at the end of the day, it's as good as instant ramen can actually be, but it was very HK and standard and I'm a fan. I also got the egg puffs which were better in consistency but I like the flavors of Genki's egg puffs a bit more. Anyways they have a lot of other noodle based dishes, rice dishes, other desserts, ice cream desserts, etc. They have just about everything. 

We also lucked out--I came for lunch around 3pm on Sunday and they open right at 3pm. Normally they're open at 5pm! BUT this place is open until 1am generally on weekdays and 2am on fri/sat evening which is amazing. Would definitely frequent this place a bit more if I didn't live so far!

tldr; awesome HK style cafe with great desserts--not sure why the reviews are so low, probably because all Chinese restaurants get screwed on service but I think the quality of the food is pretty neat
author: Jasmine X.

description:
Wow. This is perhaps my worst dining experience I've ever had in terms of service. Ever. Ever. Ever. In the history of yelp or any of my dining experiences. I was called "f*cking crazy" in Chinese after trying to speak to the manager about his employee.

I'll try to keep the story short. Came in one night for some comfort Chinese savory dishes and for some Chinese desserts after our dinner. Ordered 2 noodles, 2 appetizers, one soup, 2 drinks. I've been here at least 6+ times before and each time, we've reached the $30 dollars for check-in for the free waffle dessert. I know that we might have been a couple of dollars short so.. this is what happened

(1st interaction) - I asked the waitress in question if our party was below the $30 dollars and let me know how much we need to qualify. She comes back and says "No" and walks away.

(2nd interaction) - I asked the waitress again that if we order one more specific appetizer (for $4.50) if we would reach the $30 dollars? Answer was a simple "No," and then she walks away again. I had asked how much we needed to reach the $30 dollars but she ignored the question.

(3rd interaction) -  I waved her back politely again and asked how much it would be to reach the $30 and since she didn't answer so I asked how much we were off by if we ordered the 4.50 app. She said we were $.05 (FIVE CENTS) off. By this time, she had an annoyed smirk on her face. I tried to brush it off because I was just focused on this free dessert. I should have known by then that she was trouble.
